questions.question: Character encoding standard supporting multiple languages with variable-length encoding.
questions.explanation: UTF-8 encodes Unicode characters using 1 to 4 bytes.

questions.question: Representation of numbers that includes both magnitude and an exponent.
questions.explanation: Floating-point notation represents real numbers with fractional parts.

questions.question: IEEE standard for floating-point arithmetic widely used in computing.
questions.explanation: IEEE 754 defines binary and decimal floating-point formats.

questions.question: Error detection code adding a bit to ensure even or odd number of 1s.
questions.explanation: Parity bits detect single-bit errors in data transmission.

questions.question: Code where consecutive values differ by only one bit.
questions.explanation: Gray code minimizes errors during transitions between values.

questions.question: Excess representation adding a bias to signed numbers.
questions.explanation: Excess-N adds a constant bias to represent signed values.

questions.question: Fixed-point representation with bits reserved for fractional part.
questions.explanation: Q format allocates a fixed number of bits for integer and fractional parts.

questions.question: The special value in floating-point representing division by zero.
questions.explanation: Floating-point standards define positive and negative infinity.

questions.question: Special floating-point value for undefined operations.
questions.explanation: NaN represents results like 0/0 or square root of negative numbers.

questions.question: Method of storing the smallest addressable unit at the lowest memory address.
questions.explanation: Little-endian stores the least significant byte at the lowest address.
